{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Sara Pascoe | image = XIMG 2241.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Pascoe in 2014 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1981|5|22}} | birth_place = [[Dagenham]], London, England<ref name=EveStand2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/comedy/interview-sara-pascoe-on-female-instincts-healthy-sperm-and-her-latest-show-9583330.html|title=Interview: Sara Pascoe on female instincts, healthy sperm and her latest show|work=London Evening Standard|date=4 July 2014|author=Bruce Dessau}}</ref> | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Stand-up, television | nationality = | active = 2006–present | genre = | subject = | influences = | influenced = | spouse = | domesticpartner = | notable_work = | signature = | website = {{url|sarapascoe.co.uk/}} | footnotes = | module = }}
'''Sara Pascoe''' (born 22 May 1981){{citation needed|date=October 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--> is an English writer, stand-up comedian and actress. She has appeared on TV programmes such as ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown]]'' for [[Channel 4]], and ''[[Taskmaster (TV series)|Taskmaster]]'' for digital channel [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]].
==Early life== Pascoe was born in [[Dagenham]], east London.<ref name=EveStand2014/><ref>{{cite news |newspaper= [[The Independent]] |title= My student days: Six musicians, actors and comedians fondly reminisce |date= 14 August 2014 |author= Elisa Bray |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/student/into-university/clearing/my-student-days-six-musicians-actors-and-comedians-fondly-reminisce-9666657.html }}</ref> Her father is [[Derek Pascoe]], vocalist with 70s pop group [[Flintlock (musical group)|Flintlock]]. Her great-grandmother was the music writer [[Rosa Newmarch]].
She studied English at the [[University of Sussex]].<ref name=EveStand2014/> She later worked as a tour guide in London.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sara Pascoe at Wells Comedy Fest |work=The Bristol Magazine |url=http://thebristolmag.co.uk/sara-pascoe-wells-comedy-fest/ |year=2016 |accessdate=20 May 2017 }}</ref>
==Career== Pascoe has appeared in many television programmes and panel shows, including ''[[Stand Up for the Week]]'', ''[[The Thick of It]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret]]'', ''[[Campus (TV series)|Campus]]'', ''[[Being Human (UK TV series)|Being Human]]'', ''[[Twenty Twelve]], [[QI]] and [[W1A (TV series)|W1A]]'' as well as all-female sketch show ''Girl Friday'' (part of Channel 4's ''[[Comedy Showcase]]''), which she co-wrote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/girl_friday/ |title=Girl Friday – C4 Sketch Show – British Comedy Guide |publisher=Comedy.co.uk |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref>
She began performing stand-up in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brian Logan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/aug/07/sara-pascoe-nietzsche |title=Sara Pascoe: And now for Nietzsche ... | Stage |work=The Guardian |date=7 August 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> In August 2010, she performed her first show at the [[Edinburgh Festival]], ''Sara Pascoe Vs Her Ego''. The show received positive reviews.<ref>{{cite news|author=Julian Hall |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/reviews/sara-pascoe-vs-her-ego-pleasance-courtyard-2047951.html |title=Sara Pascoe vs Her Ego, Pleasance Courtyard – Reviews, Comedy |work=The Independent |date=10 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Duska Radosavljevic |url=http://ed.thestage.co.uk/reviews/1022 |title=Sara Pascoe vs Her Ego – The Stage / Edinburgh 2011 |work=The Stage |date=10 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref>
On 19 February 2012, she appeared on Episode 11 of the ''[[The Comedian's Comedian with Stuart Goldsmith|Comedian's Comedian Podcast]]'' hosted by [[Stuart Goldsmith]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/comedians_comedian_podcast/11_sara_pascoe/|title=Episode 11 – Sara Pascoe (Live) – The Comedian's Comedian Podcast with Stuart Goldsmith – British Comedy Guide|last=Guide|first=British Comedy|website=British Comedy Guide|access-date=5 November 2016}}</ref> In 2012, she appeared on ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g_t_wB7t5Yo|title=Sara Pascoe Live at the Apollo|date=2 December 2012|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=20 February 2015}}</ref> She appeared on [[BBC Television|BBC TV]] [[panel show]] ''[[QI]]'' in 2013 and won the episode with +28 points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b039wgpz |title=BBC Two – QI, Series K, Knees & Knockers |publisher=BBC |date=21 February 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
In 2014, she performed at the [[List of Edinburgh festivals|Edinburgh Festival]] and toured the UK for the first time with the show ''Sara Pascoe Vs History''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondthejoke.co.uk/content/835/news-sara-pascoe-announces-first-uk-tour|title=News: Sara Pascoe Announces First UK Tour|publisher=Beyond the Joke|date=29 May 2014}}</ref> The show was nominated for the Foster's [[Edinburgh Comedy Awards|Edinburgh Comedy Award]] 2014 for Best Comedy Show.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/aug/23/john-kearns-wins-the-fosters-edinburgh-comedy-award-2014|title=John Kearns wins the Foster's Edinburgh comedy award 2014|work=The Guardian|author=Brian Logan|date=23 August 2014}}</ref> In October 2014 she appeared in ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' and stood in line at the identity parade round as a former dancer and back-up singer for entertainer (and [[Robbie Williams]]'s father) Pete Conway.<ref name=Guardian1014>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2014/oct/19/sara-pascoe-vs-history-comedy-tour-interview|title=Sara Pascoe: 'Female sexuality is an active thing' |work=The Guardian|author=Stephanie Merritt|date=19 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{BBC programme|id=b04m0lzb|title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks, Series 28, Episode 3}}</ref> Also that month, she appeared on the topical panel quiz ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' as a panellist and in one of the sketches of the Channel 4 charity night ''[[Stand Up to Cancer UK|Stand Up to Cancer]]''.
In 2015, she appeared as a panellist on two Radio 4 programmes, science discussion programme ''[[The Infinite Monkey Cage]]'' in February, and comedy quiz programme ''[[The Unbelievable Truth (radio show)|The Unbelievable Truth]]'' in September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b068tsvn|title=BBC Radio 4 – The Unbelievable Truth, Series 15, Episode 3|date=23 September 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, along with numerous other celebrities, Pascoe toured the UK to support [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s bid to become [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]].<ref name="jc4pmtour">{{cite web |url=http://www.jc4pmtour.com/|title=#JC4PM|publisher=jc4pmtour|date=28 July 2015|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |last=Wilkinson|first=Michael|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/Jeremy_Corbyn/12134051/Celebrities-to-tour-Britain-in-Jeremy-Corbyn-For-Prime-Minister-musical-show.html|title=Celebrities to tour Britain in 'Jeremy Corbyn For Prime Minister' musical show|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=1 February 2016|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref>
Her first book, ''Animal: The Autobiography of a Female Body'', was published in April 2016 by [[Faber and Faber]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/comedian-tackles-female-body-faber|title=Pascoe tackles the female body for Faber |date=2 March 2015|author=Joshua Farrington|publisher=[[The Bookseller]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faber.co.uk/shop/non-fiction/science/9780571325221-animal.html|title=Animal|website=Public Store View|accessdate=19 May 2018}}</ref> In 2016 she went on tour again with the show ''Animal''. She participated in series 3 of the comedy challenge show, [[Taskmaster (TV series)|''Taskmaster'']], which aired on [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] in October and November 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/2080/taskmaster_series_3_lineup|title=Taskmaster Series 3 line-up revealed|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=16 April 2016|website=British Comedy Guide}}</ref>
She has appeared in all three of [[Frankie Boyle]]'s ''Autopsy'' BBC programmes (2014–2016), discussing political issues. In 2017 she starred in his ''[[Frankie Boyle's New World Order]]'' topical series. In 2017 she also performed a half-hour stand-up set on episode 1 of series 2 of ''[[Live from the BBC]]''.
On 27 October 2017 she appeared in an episode of British travel documentary series ''[[Travel Man]]'' on [[Channel 4]]. In February 2018, she started a [[BBC Radio 4]] series called "Modern Monkey".
In April 2018 she appeared as a panelist in two episodes of the [[BBC Radio 4]] [[panel show]] ''[[Just A Minute]]'', coming fourth in both episodes. In May 2018 she starred in a BBC comedy short entitled "Sarah Pascoe vs Monogamy."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2018/comedy-shorts|title=BBC – Sara Pascoe, Tim Key, Nick Helm and Spencer Jones make new BBC Comedy Shorts – Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
==Personal life== Pascoe is a [[vegan]].<ref>http://www.sarapascoe.com/veganism.html</ref> She lives in London.
From 2013 to late 2016, Pascoe dated comedian [[John Robins (comedian)|John Robins]],<ref name=EveStand2014 /><ref name=Guardian1014 /> and her reflections on that relationship and its aftermath are the basis of her 2017 show ''LadsLadsLads'' at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/aug/05/sara-pascoe-lads-lads-lads-review-pleasance-courtyard-edinburgh |author=Brian Logan |title=Sara Pascoe: LadsLadsLads review – breakup tales from a woman reborn |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=5 August 2017 }}</ref>
